  "overview": "The purpose of this Act is to make the women's court pilot program in the first circuit permanent. [CHUNK_6] It also seeks to establish a three-year women's court pilot program in the circuit court of the Kona division of the third circuit. [CHUNK_7] Additionally, the bill requires the judiciary to submit a report to the legislature regarding the need for and the associated costs of a pilot program for women's court in other circuits. [CHUNK_8]",
  "appropriations": "This measure appropriates an unspecified sum out of the general revenues of the State of Hawaii for fiscal year 2025-2026 and an unspecified sum for fiscal year 2026-2027. [CHUNK_18] The sums appropriated shall be expended by the judiciary. [CHUNK_19]",
  "assumptions_and_methodology": "The provided documents do not specify the assumptions or methodology used to determine the necessary appropriation amounts, as the sums are left blank in the bill. [CHUNK_17] The goal of the pilot program is to divert participants from incarceration, support their success in the community, and reduce recidivism by implementing trauma-informed and evidence-based practices. [CHUNK_11] The services offered are intended to address areas such as trauma, family support, life-skills, and substance abuse treatment. [CHUNK_12]",
  "agency_impact": "The judiciary is tasked with making the women's court pilot program in the first circuit permanent. [CHUNK_6] It will also establish and supervise a new women's court pilot program within the third circuit Kona division. [CHUNK_10] The judiciary is also required to submit reports to the legislature regarding the new pilot program and the potential need for similar programs in other circuits. [CHUNK_14] [CHUNK_20]",
  "economic_impact": "The program aims to divert participants from incarceration, support their success in the community, and reduce recidivism. [CHUNK_11] It is intended to acknowledge the distinct pathways that lead women into the criminal justice system and address their individualized needs. [CHUNK_7] The legislature finds that women offenders face unique barriers to success after incarceration, including being primary caregivers, having lower educational attainment, and lacking stable work history. [CHUNK_3]",
  "policy_impact": "This Act makes the women's court pilot program in the first circuit permanent by amending Act 243, Session Laws of Hawaii 2022, to remove its repeal date. [CHUNK_9] It establishes a new, temporary three-year Women's Court Pilot Program within the Kona division of the Third Circuit. [CHUNK_10] [CHUNK_22] It also requires the judiciary to report on the need for and associated costs of a pilot program in the second and fifth circuits and the Hilo division of the third circuit. [CHUNK_8]",
  "revenue_sources": "The bill appropriates funds out of the general revenues of the State of Hawaii. [CHUNK_17] The sums for fiscal years 2025-2026 and 2026-2027 are unspecified in this version of the bill. [CHUNK_17] No other revenue sources are identified in the provided documents. [CHUNK_17]",
  "six_year_fiscal_implications": "The measure appropriates an unspecified amount from general revenues for FY 2025-2026 and FY 2026-2027 for the Kona pilot program. [CHUNK_17] The Kona pilot is a three-year program, which suggests funding will also be needed in FY 2027-2028. [CHUNK_7] Part III of the Act, establishing the Kona pilot, is repealed on June 30, 2028. [CHUNK_22] The bill makes the first circuit's women's court pilot program permanent, creating an ongoing fiscal obligation that is not funded by this measure. [CHUNK_6] [CHUNK_9] The judiciary must submit a report before the 2026 session on the costs of potential pilot programs in other circuits. [CHUNK_20] Additionally, the judiciary is required to submit reports to the legislature prior to the 2026, 2027, and 2028 sessions on the status of the Kona pilot, which will inform future fiscal decisions. [CHUNK_14] The recommendations in these reports will address whether the program should continue, expand, or be discontinued. [CHUNK_16]",
  "operating_revenue_impact": "The provided legislative documents do not indicate any anticipated impact on operating revenues. [CHUNK_17]",
  "capital_expenditure_impact": "The provided legislative documents do not specify any capital expenditures. [CHUNK_18] Appropriations are designated for mental health, substance abuse treatment, other services, and the establishment of two temporary positions. [CHUNK_18] No funds are allocated for facilities or major equipment. [CHUNK_19]",
  "fiscal_implications_after_6_years": "Part III of the act, establishing the women's court pilot program in the third circuit Kona division, is repealed on June 30, 2028, ending its fiscal obligations. [CHUNK_22] However, the measure makes the Women's Court Pilot Program in the First Circuit permanent, which will result in ongoing fiscal implications beyond the six-year period. [CHUNK_6] [CHUNK_9] The costs associated with the permanent first circuit program are not specified in this measure. [CHUNK_17]",
  "updates_from_previous_fiscal_note": "The most significant change from the previous fiscal note is the removal of specific appropriation amounts. [CHUNK_17] The previous note specified appropriations of $514,900 (HB727_SD1_.HTM.txt) for FY 2025-2026 and $557,000 (HB727_SD1_.HTM.txt) for FY 2026-2027. [CHUNK_17] The current version of the bill, HB727 SD2, leaves these appropriation amounts blank. [CHUNK_17] Other aspects of the bill, such as the creation of two temporary FTEs, the establishment of the Kona pilot program, making the first circuit program permanent, reporting requirements, the sunset date for the pilot, and the effective date, remain consistent with the details described in the previous fiscal note. [CHUNK_6] [CHUNK_18] [CHUNK_22]",
  "fte_positions": "The measure appropriates funds for the establishment of two temporary positions. [CHUNK_18] These positions are one full-time equivalent (1.0 FTE) Kona drug court probation supervisor position and one full-time equivalent (1.0 FTE) peer specialist position. [CHUNK_18] These positions are for the women's court pilot program established in the Kona division of the third circuit. [CHUNK_19]",
  "appropriations_changes": "Appropriations in a prior version were specified, but this version of the bill has been amended to leave the appropriation amounts blank. [CHUNK_17] The bill appropriates the sum of $ (HB727_SD2) for fiscal year 2025-2026 and $ (HB727_SD2) for fiscal year 2026-2027. [CHUNK_17] The purpose of the appropriation for services and two temporary positions remains the same. [CHUNK_18]",
  "funding_sources_changes": "The funding source remains the general revenues of the State of Hawaii. [CHUNK_17] There is no change to the method of funding from the previous fiscal note. [CHUNK_17] The only change is that the amount to be appropriated from the general fund is now unspecified. [CHUNK_17]",
  "department_impact": "This version of the bill maintains that the sums appropriated shall be expended by the judiciary. [CHUNK_19] There are no changes to the department responsible for expending the funds compared to the previous fiscal note. [CHUNK_19] The judiciary is responsible for the purposes of this Act. [CHUNK_19]",
  "reports_required": "The judiciary is required to submit a report to the legislature no later than forty days prior to the convening of the regular session of 2026 regarding the need for and associated costs of a pilot program in the second and fifth circuits and the Hilo division of the third circuit. [CHUNK_20] [CHUNK_21] Additionally, the judiciary must submit reports on the status of the Kona pilot program prior to the regular sessions of 2026, 2027, and 2028. [CHUNK_14] These reporting requirements are unchanged from the previous fiscal note. [CHUNK_14]",
  "pilot_program": "This measure makes the women's court pilot program in the first circuit permanent. [CHUNK_6] It also establishes a three-year women's court pilot program in the circuit court of the Kona division of the third circuit. [CHUNK_7] [CHUNK_10] This is consistent with the information in the previous fiscal note. [CHUNK_6]",
  "sunset_date": "Part III of the Act, which establishes the Kona pilot program, shall be repealed on June 30, 2028. [CHUNK_22] The bill also amends Act 243, Session Laws of Hawaii 2022, to remove the June 30, 2025 repeal date for the first circuit program, making it permanent. [CHUNK_9]",
  "effective_date": "This Act shall take effect on April 23, 2057. [CHUNK_21] This effective date remains unchanged from the previous version discussed in the prior fiscal note. [CHUNK_21]"
}

PART I SECTION 1. The legislature finds that there has been a significant increase in the number of women in Hawai ` i jails and prisons over the past forty years, resulting in a higher proportion of women who are incarcerated. Research reflects that for women, histories of abuse, trauma,

incarcerated. 2022, established a three-year women's court pilot program in the circuit court of the first circuit. This program, known as Mohala Wahine, focuses on non-violent women who are at high risk of recidivism and in need of multiple services such as substance abuse treatment, therapy, or housing. The program began

as substance abuse treatment, therapy, or housing. The program began accepting participants in January 2023, with a goal of admitting twenty women each year. shall be established within the third circuit Kona division of the judiciary the women's court pilot program. overview.prompt: Using the provided legislative documents, statutes, and testimonies, write a clear summary describing the purpose, scope, and key components of the proposed measure or bill, including any pilot or permanent programs, reporting requirements, and sunset clauses. This should be around 3 sentences.
overview.description: General overview and summary of the measure

appropriations.prompt: Based on budgetary data and legislative appropriations, detail the funding allocated for the program or measure, including fiscal years, amounts, intended uses such as staffing, training, contracts, technology, etc... This should be around 3 sentences.

assumptions_and_methodology.prompt: Explain the assumptions, cost estimation methods, and data sources used to calculate the financial projections for this program or measure, referencing comparable programs or historical budgets where applicable. This should be around 3 sentences.

agency_impact.prompt: Describe the anticipated operational, administrative, and budgetary impact of the program or measure on the relevant government agency or department, including supervision, staffing, and resource allocation. This should be around 3 sentences.
agency_impact.description: Impact on government agencies and departments

economic_impact.prompt: Summarize the expected economic effects of the program or measure, such as cost savings, potential reductions in related expenditures, benefits to the community, and any relevant performance or participation statistics. This should be around 3 sentences.

policy_impact.prompt: Analyze the policy implications of the measure, including how it modifies existing laws or programs, its role within broader legislative strategies, and its potential effects on state or local governance. This should be around 3 sentences.

revenue_sources.prompt: Identify and describe the funding sources that will support the program or measure, such as general funds, grants, fees, or other revenue streams, based on the provided fiscal documents. This should be around 3 sentences.

six_year_fiscal_implications.prompt: Provide a multi-year fiscal outlook (e.g., six years) for the program or measure, projecting costs, staffing changes, recurring expenses, and assumptions about program expansion or permanence using available budget and workload data. This should be around 10 sentences.

operating_revenue_impact.prompt: Describe any anticipated impacts on operating revenues resulting from the program or measure, including increases, decreases, or changes in revenue streams. This should be around 3 sentences.

capital_expenditure_impact.prompt: Outline any expected capital expenditures related to the program or measure, such as investments in facilities, equipment, or technology infrastructure, based on capital budgets or agency plans. This should be around 3 sentences.

fiscal_implications_after_6_years.prompt: Summarize the ongoing fiscal obligations after the initial multi-year period for the program or measure, including annual operating costs, expected number of program sites or units, and the sustainability of funding. This should be around 3 sentences.
fiscal_implications_after_6_years.description: Long-term fiscal obligations beyond six years

updates_from_previous_fiscal_note.prompt: If you are given a previous fiscal note. Please summarize the MAIN POINTS that are different from the previous fiscal note and the new fiscal note.

fte_positions.prompt: Detail any Full Time Equivalent (FTE) positions that have been added or modified in this version of the bill, including the number of positions, their roles, and any changes from previous versions. This should be around 3 sentences.

appropriations_changes.prompt: Identify and describe any appropriations that were previously unspecified or have been modified between versions of the bill, including the amounts and purposes of the appropriations. This should be around 3 sentences.
appropriations_changes.description: Changes to appropriations between bill versions

funding_sources_changes.prompt: Specify the method of funding (MOF) for appropriations and identify any changes in funding sources between versions, such as shifts between general fund and special fund appropriations. This should be around 3 sentences.
funding_sources_changes.description: Changes to funding sources and method of funding

department_impact.prompt: Describe any changes in which department is responsible for expending appropriations, including shifts from one department to another between bill versions (e.g., from Department of Health to Judiciary). This should be around 3 sentences.
department_impact.description: Changes in department responsibility for appropriations

reports_required.prompt: Identify any reports that agencies are required to submit to the legislature, including new reporting requirements or modifications to existing ones. This should be around 3 sentences.

pilot_program.prompt: If the bill creates a pilot program, describe the length of the pilot program and whether it was initially intended to be a pilot program or a permanent program. This should be around 3 sentences.

sunset_date.prompt: Identify the sunset date for the bill or program, including any modifications to the sunset date between versions. This should be around 2 sentences.

effective_date.prompt: Identify the effective date of the bill, noting if there was a defective effective date in a previous version and what the corrected effective date is. This should be around 2 sentences.

BE IT ENACTED BY THE LEGISLATURE OF THE STATE OF HAWAII: PART I SECTION 1. The legislature finds that there has

PART I SECTION 1. The legislature finds that there has been a significant increase in the number of women in Hawai ` i jails and prisons over the past forty years, resulting in a higher proportion of women who are incarcerated. Research reflects that for women, histories of abuse, trauma,

incarcerated. Research reflects that for women, histories of abuse, trauma, poverty, mental illness, substance use disorders, and unhealthy relationships intersect with their entry into criminal behavior. Women offenders also face unique barriers to success after incarceration. They are more likely to be primary caregivers for young children, have lower educational

to be primary caregivers for young children, have lower educational attainment, lack stable work history, and experience economic or social marginalization, which prevents them from having more positive outcomes. The legislature further finds that Act 243, Session Laws of Hawaii 2022, established a three-year women's court pilot program in the

2022, established a three-year women's court pilot program in the circuit court of the first circuit. This program, known as Mohala Wahine, focuses on non-violent women who are at high risk of recidivism and in need of multiple services such as substance abuse treatment, therapy, or housing. The program began

as substance abuse treatment, therapy, or housing. The program began accepting participants in January 2023, with a goal of admitting twenty women each year. As of August 2024, twenty-three women are currently participating in the program, with eleven participants in phase one of treatment and twelve participants in phase two

phase one of treatment and twelve participants in phase two of treatment. The purpose of this Act is to: (1) Make the women's court pilot program in the first circuit permanent; (2) Establish a three-year women's court pilot program in the circuit court of the Kona division of the third

the circuit court of the Kona division of the third circuit, which is intended to acknowledge the distinct pathways that lead women into the criminal justice system and address their individualized needs; and (3) Require the judiciary to submit a report to the legislature regarding the need for and the

report to the legislature regarding the need for and the associated costs of a pilot program for women's court in the second and fifth circuits and Hilo division of the third circuit. PART II SECTION 2. Act 243, Session Laws of Hawaii 2022, is amended by amending section 5 to

of Hawaii 2022, is amended by amending section 5 to read as follows: "SECTION 5. This Act shall take effect on July 1, 2022[ , and shall be repealed on June 30, 2025 ]." PART III SECTION 3. (a) There shall be established within the third circuit Kona division of

shall be established within the third circuit Kona division of the judiciary the women's court pilot program. The women's court pilot program shall be under the supervision of the big island drug court. The pilot program shall implement trauma-informed and evidence-based practices, employ gender-responsive programming, collaborate with stakeholders, and provide

evidence-based practices, employ gender-responsive programming, collaborate with stakeholders, and provide services to women in the court system with the goal of diverting participants from incarceration, supporting their success in the community, and reducing recidivism. (b) The services offered by the pilot program shall address the following areas: (1) Trauma and

pilot program shall address the following areas: (1) Trauma and mental health treatment; (2) Family support, including parenting, education, and relationship improvement; (3) Life-skills training; (4) Education and vocational training; (5) Domestic violence prevention; (6) Medical services and health education; (7) Substance abuse detection, prevention, and treatment; (8) Mentoring; and

(7) Substance abuse detection, prevention, and treatment; (8) Mentoring; and (9) Housing support. SECTION 4. women who were eligible to participate in the women's court pilot program but who could not be accepted into the pilot program because of pilot program limitations; (4) The number of women completing the women's court pilot program; (5) The number of women who were removed from the women's court

Chapter 304A, Hawaii Revised Statutes, is amended by adding to part V, subpart D, a new section to be appropriately designated and to read as follows: " §304A- University of Hawaii conference center revolving fund. (a) There is established the university of Hawaii conference center revolving fund for conference

the university of Hawaii conference center revolving fund for conference center programs conducted by the university. The university may establish and collect fees and charges for the costs of providing these services. All fees, charges, and other moneys collected in conjunction with the conference center programs of the university shall

conjunction with the conference center programs of the university shall be deposited in separate accounts within the revolving fund. The university may establish accounts under the university of Hawaii conference center revolving fund to facilitate the administration of this fund among the various campuses and operating units of the university

among the various campuses and operating units of the university of Hawaii system.
